person_300.name: Déodat Gratet deDolomieu
person_300.description: French geologist. The rock, and region of the Alps, dolomite was named after him.

person_501.name: Charles Étienne Coquebert deMontbret
person_501.description: French diplomat and traveller who became professor of mining statistics at the École des mines.

person_265.name: Peter SimonPallas
person_265.description: Prussian explorer, geologist and botanist, who wrote 'Second Voyage de Pallas, ou Voyages entrpris dans les gouvernmens meridionaux de l'empire de Russie, pendant les annees 1793 et 94'

person_505.name: EdmondHalley
person_505.description: Astronomer and natural philosopher, who, using Newtonian mechanics, predicted the return of what became the eponymous comet. FRSL.

person_388.name: Georg ErnstStahl
person_388.description: German physician, chemist and philosopher who strongly promoted the phlogiston theory.

person_030.name: Antoine-LaurentLavoisier
person_030.description: French chemist and tax farmer (for which he was guillotined). Developed a new nomenclature for chemistry (much of which is still in use today) and argued strongly against the existence of phlogiston. Davy read some of his writings while in Cornwall which he then opposed and throughout his career maintained an ambivalent attitude towards Lavoisierian chemisty. ForMemRSL.

person_387.name: John JoachimBecher
person_387.description: German physician and alchemist. Davy gives him incorrect dates in notebook 15E.

person_103.name: RobertBoyle
person_103.description: Irish-born chemist and one of the founders of modern chemistry. FRSL.

person_653.name: Otto vonGuericke
person_653.description: German natural philosopher, inventor and politician who worked mostly in Magdeburg.

person_955.name: Constantine
person_955.description: Roman emperor from AD 306 to 337; he patronised Christianity and was converted to it on his deathbed.

place_146.name: Portrush
place_146.description: A small seaside town on north coast of County Antrim, Northern Ireland.

place_126.name: Giant's Causeway
place_126.description: The Giant's Causeway is an extensive area of columnar basalt in County Antrim, Northern Ireland, formed by an ancient volcanic fissure eruption.

place_1261.name: Auvergne
place_1261.description: A region of central France known for its mountain ranges and dormant volcanoes.

place_503.name: Westerwaldkreis
place_503.description: Westerwald is a low range of mountains, the highest point being 657m, on the banks of the Rhine in Germany.

place_132.name: Fairhead
place_132.description: Fairhead is a spectacular 5km long, 82m high cliff above the sea at Ballycastle, County Antrim, Northern Ireland. It is a dolerite sill.

place_505.name: Montfaucon, Doubs
place_505.description: There are several Mountfaucons in France, and this one in Switzerland. This one refers to a municipality in the Jura region.

place_506.name: Konsnetsk
place_506.description: Konsnetsk appears to be a small town or village in Siberia. It could be the town of Kuznetsk, Russia.

place_021.name: Cornwall
place_021.description: Cornwall is a county in south-west England, birthplace of Humphry Davy.

place_121.name: England
place_121.description: England is a country that is part of the United Kingdom. It is located on the island of Great Britain, of which it covers approximately 62%, and over 100 smaller adjacent islands.

place_071.name: London
place_071.description: The capital city of England and the United Kingdom.

place_508.name: Land's End
place_508.description: Land's End is a headland on the west coast of Cornwall. It is the most westerly point of mainland England. The underlying rock at Land's End is granite.

place_509.name: Lizard Point
place_509.description: The Lizard is a peninsula of the southern coast of Cornwall. It is the most southerly point of the British mainland. The geology of the Lizard is complex: it contains some of Cornwall's oldest (Precambrian) rocks, as well as heavily metamorphosed rocks.

place_908.name: Land's End
place_908.description: A headland in western Cornwall, the most westerly point of mainland England.

place_419.name: Mount's Bay
place_419.description: A bay on the English Channel coast of Cornwall, England, stretching from the Lizard Point to Gwennap Head.

place_520.name: Kynance Cove
place_520.description: Kynance Cove lies to the east of Mount's Bay in Cornwall, on the Lizard Peninsula.

place_013.name: St Michael's Mount
place_013.description: St Michael's Mount is a tidal island in Mount's Bay, Cornwall, with a distinct conical shape.

place_522.name: Coverack
place_522.description: Coverack is a coastal village and fishing port on the eastern side of the Lizard Peninsula.

place_525.name: Mullion, Cornwall
place_525.description: Mullion is a village on the Lizard Peninsula, Cornwall.

place_521.name: Gunwalloe
place_521.description: Gunwalloe is a coastal village on the western coast of the Lizard Peninsula in Cornwall.

place_523.name: Cape Cornwall
place_523.description: Cape Cornwall is a headland north of Land's End.

place_511.name: Breage, Cornwall
place_511.description: Breage is a village on the southern coast of Cornwall, near the middle of Mount's Bay.

place_786.name: Falmouth
place_786.description: Falmouth is a town on the south coast of Cornwall.

place_796.name: Plymouth
place_796.description: Plymouth is a port city in the south-west of England

place_797.name: Hartland
place_797.description: Hartland is a village on the coast in Devon.

place_798.name: Pendeen
place_798.description: Pendeen is a village and ecclesiastical parish on the Penwith peninsula in Cornwall.

place_512.name: Mousehole Island
place_512.description: Mousehole is a village south of Penzance on the western shore of Mount's Bay, Cornwall. The island Davy refers to is probably St Clement's Isle, off the coast of Mousehole.

place_799.name: Boat Cove
place_799.description: A small beach in Cornwall also known as Pendeen Cove.

place_516.name: Zennor
place_516.description: Zennor is a village on the north coast of Cornwall.

place_517.name: Longships
place_517.description: Longships is the name given to a group of rocky islets west of Land's End, Cornwall.

place_016.name: Mousehole
place_016.description: Mousehole is a village and fishing port in Cornwall.

place_514.name: Castle Treen
place_514.description: Treryn Dinas is a headland on the Penwith Peninsula, Cornwall.

place_397.name: Dartmoor
place_397.description: Dartmoor is an upland area of southern Devon, England.

place_802.name: Rough Tor
place_802.description: Rough Tor or Roughtor, is a tor on Bodmin Moor, Cornwall

place_803.name: Brownwilly
place_803.description: Brown Willy is the highest point of Bodmin Moor and of Cornwall.

place_804.name: Caradon Hill
place_804.description: A hill on Bodmin Moor, Cornwall.

place_814.name: River Fowey
place_814.description: The River Fowey is in Cornwall. Its source is on Bodmin Moor.

place_1011.name: Morton
place_1011.description: A castle located by an artificial loch in the hills above Nithsdale, in Dumfries and Galloway, south-west Scotland.

place_047.name: Donegal
place_047.description: Donegal is a town at the mouth of the River Eske, in north-west Ireland.

place_494.name: Mourne Mountains
place_494.description: Slieve Donard is located in the Mourne Mountains of County Down, Northern Ireland. It is Northern Ireland's highest mountain at 850m.
